specJson.name: brightics.function.clustering$agglomerative_clustering
specJson.description:
Agglomerative clustering is the most common type of hierarchical clustering using a bottom-up approach. Hierarchical clustering is a method of cluster analysis which seeks to build a hierarchy of clusters. Strategies for hierarchical clustering generally fall into two types; 1) Bottom-up approach: each observation starts in its own cluster, and pairs of clusters are merged as one moves up the hierarchy. 2) Top-down approach: all observations start in one cluster, and splits are performed recursively as one moves down the hierarchy.

Agglomerative clustering algorithm starts by treating each observation as a single cluster. At each step of the algorithm, the two clusters that are the most similar are combined into a new bigger cluster. This procedure is iterated until all observations are member of just one single big cluster. The result of the clustering is visualized as a dendrogram, which shows the sequence of cluster merging and the distance at which each merging took place. With output table, it shows cluster informtation joined at each iteration, height and the number of original observations in the newly formed cluster.

There are two main parameters user can choose; `Linkage Method`, `Metric`. First, `Linkage Method` determines which distance to use between sets of observation. There are serveral linkage criteria supported such as `Single`, `Average`, `Complete`, `Ward`. Second, `Metric` determines which metric to use to compute the option of `Linkage Method`. There are such options like `Euclidean`, `Minkowski`, `Cityblock`. Result of this function can be varied widely depending on the chosen `Linkage Method` and `Metric`. For more information to get some intuition about the characteristics of differenct linkage methods for hierarchical clustering, read the reference below.

Reference
+ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering>
+ <https://www.datanovia.com/en/lessons/agglomerative-hierarchical-clustering/>

params.label: Input Columns
params.description: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: Linkage
params.description:
Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `Ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `Complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `Average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `Single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets.
   - Available Options : `ward`, `complete`, `average`, `single`

params.label: Affinity
params.description:
Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted.
   - Available Options : `euclidean`, `l1`, `l2`, `manhattan`, `cosine`

params.label: N Clusters
params.description:
The number of clusters to find.
   - Available Options : `True`, `False`

params.label: Compute Full Tree
params.description: Stop early the construction of the tree at n_clusters. This is useful to decrease computation time if the number of clusters is not small compared to the number of samples. This option is useful only when specifying a connectivity matrix. Note also that when varying the number of clusters and using caching, it may be advantageous to compute the full tree.

summary.en: This function trains an agglomerative clustering model and predicts cluster label.
summary.ko: 병합 군집 모델을 학습시키고 군집 레이블을 예측합니다.

md.en:
# Agglomerative Clustering This function trains an agglomerative clustering model and predicts cluster label. ## Description Agglomerative clustering is the most common type of hierarchical clustering using a bottom-up approach. Hierarchical clustering is a method of cluster analysis which seeks to build a hierarchy of clusters. Strategies for hierarchical clustering generally fall into two types; 1) Bottom-up approach: each observation starts in its own cluster, and pairs of clusters are merged as one moves up the hierarchy. 2) Top-down approach: all observations start in one cluster, and splits are performed recursively as one moves down the hierarchy. Agglomerative clustering algorithm starts by treating each observation as a single cluster. At each step of the algorithm, the two clusters that are the most similar are combined into a new bigger cluster. This procedure is iterated until all observations are member of just one single big cluster. The result of the clustering is visualized as a dendrogram, which shows the sequence of cluster merging and the distance at which each merging took place. With output table, it shows cluster information joined at each iteration, height and the number of original observations in the newly formed cluster. There are two main parameters user can choose; `Linkage Method`, `Metric`. First, `Linkage Method` determines which distance to use between sets of observation. There are several linkage criteria supported such as `Single`, `Average`, `Complete`, `Ward`. Second, `Metric` determines which metric to use to compute the option of `Linkage Method`. There are such options like `Euclidean`, `Minkowski`, `Cityblock`. Result of this function can be varied widely depending on the chosen `Linkage Method` and `Metric`. For more information to get some intuition about the characteristics of different linkage methods for hierarchical clustering, read the reference below. Reference + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) A result table that contains input table and cluster label. 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Agglomerative Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **Prediction Column Name**: Column name for prediction. 3. **Linkage**: Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `Ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `Complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `Average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `Single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. 4. **Affinity**: Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted. 5. **N Clusters**: The number of clusters to find. 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: Compute Full Tree Mode. 7. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` agglomerative_clustering(table = , input_cols = , prediction_col = , linkage = , affinity = , n_clusters = , compute_full_tree_auto = , compute_full_tree = , group_by = ) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (Table) A result table that contains input table and cluster label. 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Agglomerative Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **prediction_col**: Column name for prediction. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: prediction 3. **linkage**: Which linkage criterion to use. The linkage criterion determines which distance to use between sets of observation. The algorithm will merge the pairs of cluster that minimize this criterion. `ward` is a variance-minimizing approach and use the sum of squared differences within all clusters. `complete` uses the maximum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. `average` uses the average of the distances between all observations of pairs of sets. `single` uses the minimum of the distances between all observations of the two sets. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: ward ( ward | complete | average | single ) 4. **affinity**: Metric used to compute the linkage. Note that if linkage is `ward`, only `euclidean` is accepted. * Type: *str* * Default / Range: euclidean ( euclidean | l1 | l2 | manhattan | cosine ) 5. **n_clusters**: The number of clusters to find. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 2 (value >= 1) 6. **compute_full_tree_auto**: Compute Full Tree Mode. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: true 7. **compute_full_tree**: Stop early the construction of the tree at n_clusters. This is useful to decrease computation time if the number of clusters is not small compared to the number of samples. This option is useful only when specifying a connectivity matrix. Note also that when varying the number of clusters and using caching, it may be advantageous to compute the full tree. * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: None 8. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Sample Model]**
In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used in the Agglomerative Clustering function. The generated table shows cluster label for each data point. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Prediction Column Name**: prediction 3. **Linkage**: ward 4. **Affinity**: euclidean 5. **N Clusters**: 3 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: true 7. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.clustering import agglomerative_clustering input_table = inputs[0] result = agglomerative_clustering(table=input_table, input_cols=['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], prediction_col='prediction', linkage='ward', affinity='euclidean', n_clusters=3, compute_full_tree_auto=True, compute_full_tree=None, group_by=None) output_table = result['out_table'] output_model = result['model'] ```
In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used in the Agglomerative Clustering function. The generated table shows cluster label for each data point.
md.kr:
# 병합 군집 이 함수는 응집형 클러스터링은 각 데이터에서 시작해서 유사한(즉, 가까운) 데이터끼리 순차적으로 클러스터를 묶어나가며 클러스터 라벨(label)을 부여한다. ## Description 계층적클러스터링(Hierarchical_clustering)은 크게 Bottom-up 방식과 Top-down으로 나누어진다. 응집형 클러스터링은 가장 보편적인 Bottom-up 방식이다. >Bottom-up 원리 1) n개의 클러스터로 시작한다. 최초의 클러스터는 1개의 개체(데이터)만 가지고 있다. 2) 클러스터 간 거리 행렬을 측정한다. 3) 가장 가까운 클러스터끼리 응집해서(합쳐서) 하나의 더 큰 클러스터로 만든다. 4) 가장 큰 클러스터 1개만 남을 때까지 2. 3. 과정을 반복해서 클러스터를 합친다.
응집형 클러스터링을 사용할 때는 중요한 2개의 파라미터가 있다. - `Linkage Method` : 클러스터룰 연결하는(합치는) 방식을 결정한다. - `Metric` : 클러스터 간 거리를 측정하는 방식을 결정한다.
Reference + + ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (테이블) 응집형 클러스터링에 사용할 데이터 입력 테이블 #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (테이블) 개체별로 Prediction Column에 클러스터 번호(라벨)가 부여된 결과 2. **model**: (모델) 학습된 응집형 클러스터링 모델 #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: 클러스터링 기준으로 사용할 input 컬럼들. *숫자 타입만 가능 2. **Prediction Column Name**: 클러스터링 번호(라벨)가 부여되는 컬럼의 이름을 입력 3. **Linkage**: 클러스터 연결 방식 `Ward` : 두 클러스터 간 거리행렬을 구할 때의 오차제곱합(error sum of squares)의 증분을 거리로 사용 `Complete` : 두 클러스터의 개체들 중 가장 멀리 떨어진 두 점 간의 거리 사용 `Average` : 두 클러스터의 개체들을 모두 짝을 지어 계산한 평균 거리 사용 `Single` : 두 클러스터에 속한 가장 가까운 두 점 사이의 거리 사용 - Reference + 4. **Affinity**: 클러스터 연결할 때 거리 계산방법을 선택. `ward` 는 오직 `euclidean`만 사용 가능. - Reference + 5. **N Clusters**: 클러스터의 개수 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: 전체 트리를 계산하여 연산량을 줄이는 옵션 * 일반적으로 클러스터 개수가 100개 이하 또는 0.02*n_samples개 이하일 때 `true` 사용 7. **Group By**: 특정 컬럼으로 그룹화 ### Python #### USAGE ``` agglomerative_clustering(table = , input_cols = , prediction_col = , linkage = , affinity = , n_clusters = , compute_full_tree_auto = , compute_full_tree = , group_by = ) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (테이블) 응집형 클러스터링에 사용할 데이터 입력 테이블 #### OUTPUT 1. **table**: (테이블) 개체별로 Prediction Column에 클러스터 번호(라벨)가 부여된 결과 2. **model**: (모델) 학습된 응집형 클러스터링 모델 #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: 클러스터링 기준으로 사용할 input 컬럼들. *숫자 타입만 가능 * Type: *list[str]* 2. **prediction_col**: 개체별로 클러스터 번호(라벨)가 부여된 결과 * Type: *str* * Default / Range: prediction 3. **linkage**: 클러스터 연결 방식 * Type: *str* * Default / Range: ward ( ward | complete | average | single ) `Ward` : 두 클러스터 간 거리행렬을 구할 때의 오차제곱합(error sum of squares)의 증분을 거리로 사용 `Complete` : 두 클러스터의 개체들 중 가장 멀리 떨어진 두 점 간의 거리 사용 `Average` : 두 클러스터의 개체들을 모두 짝을 지어 계산한 평균 거리 사용 `Single` : 두 클러스터에 속한 가장 가까운 두 점 사이의 거리 사용 4. **affinity**: 클러스터 연결할 때 거리 계산방법을 선택. `ward` 는 오직 `euclidean`만 사용 가능 * Type: *str* * Default / Range: euclidean ( euclidean | l1 | l2 | manhattan | cosine ) 5. **n_clusters**: 클러스터의 개수 * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 2 (value >= 1) 6. **compute_full_tree_auto**: 모든 트리에 대해 계산 * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: true 7. **compute_full_tree**: 전체 트리를 계산하여 연산량을 줄이는 옵션 * 일반적으로 클러스터 개수가 100개 이하 또는 0.02*n_samples개 이하일 때 `true` 사용 * Type: *boolean* * Default / Range: None 8. **group_by**: 특정 컬럼으로 그룹화 * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]** 위 brightics 튜토리얼에서는 sample_iris 데이터를 사용한다.
식당의 각 코너별 이용 비율을 통해 고객의 유형을 클러스터링하여 성별,연령별 특성을 분석하는 데 활용한다. 고객의 Segmentation을 분석하고자 할 때 유용하게 활용가능한다. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Prediction Column Name**: prediction 3. **Linkage**: ward 4. **Affinity**: euclidean 5. **N Clusters**: 3 6. **Compute Full Tree Auto**: true 7. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.clustering import agglomerative_clustering input_table = inputs[0] result = agglomerative_clustering(table=input_table, input_cols=['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], prediction_col='prediction', linkage='ward', affinity='euclidean', n_clusters=3, compute_full_tree_auto=True, compute_full_tree=None, group_by=None) output_table = result['out_table'] output_model = result['model'] ``` 위 Python 튜토리얼은 sample_iris 데이터를 사용한다.
iris는 붓꽃 종류별 잎과 받침의 가로, 세로 길이를 가지고 있는 데이터이다. 꽃잎과 꽃받침의 가로, 세로 길이를 응집형 클러스터링을 통해 n개의 클러스터 구분해내는 모델을 학습시키고, 새로운 데이터가 들어왔을 때 붓꽃의 종류(Species)를 예측(분류)해낼 수 있는 모델을 만들 수 있다. 클러스터링은 비지도 학습법이기 때문에 Label(정답)을 모르고 있어도 학습이 가능하다는 장점이 있다. * Brightics 튜토리얼 링크 (전처리 참고) + * 데이터 다운로드 링크 + + * 파이썬 함수 Reference: +

guide.message: Set data options using Chart Setting Button.
